frameDefinitions: The words in this frame refer to what Clothing the Wearer (or a specific Body_part of the Wearer) has on.
An Agent resolves an outstanding Problem by finding its solution, explanation, answer, etc.
Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer being aware (or not being aware) of the difference between two Phenomena, which may be expressed jointly or disjointly.
A Landmark (in combination with the image schema evoked by particular targets) serves to pick out the final location of a Trajector in a construed or actual motion event.
This frame concerns the infliction of punishment in return for a wrong suffered.
This frame characterizes the situation or state of affairs in which someone acts to prevent a Fire_disaster from occurring, accelerating, or affecting any area not identified as a Controlled_area.
frameExamples: I <t>had</t> <t>on</t> the most ridiculous monkey-suit you could imagine.
As it turns out, putting all of my eggs in one basket completely <t>solved</t> all of my problems.
It is very difficult for people to visually <t>distinguish</t> between living and non-living things from such a great distance .
Flights <t>into</t> Denver are not permitted at this time.
(1) They took <t>revenge</t> for the deaths of two loyalist prisoners.
listRoleDefinitions: The person whose clothing is under discussion.
This role identifies the <fen>Clothing</fen> that the <fen>Wearer</fen> wears.
The body part of the <fen>Wearer</fen> which is covered by the <fen>Clothing</fen>.
The time at or during which the <fen>Wearer</fen> has the <fen>Clothing</fen> on.
The <fen>Agent</fen> finds the solution or explanation to the outstanding mystery or <fen>Problem</fen>.
The <fen>Problem</fen> is the predicament or mystery that is resolved.
The <fen>Cause</fen> is the non-Agentive event or state of affairs that brings about the resolution of the <fen>Problem</fen>.
This role indicates the <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Problem</fen> is resolved.
This role indicates the location at which the <fen>Problem</fen> is resolved.
The cognizer is the person (or other sentient being) who potentially determines that two Phenomena are distinct from each other. It is normally expressed as an External Argument:

The phenomena that are potentially judged to be different from one another can be expressed as separate constituents. When they are, one is typically expressed as an NP Object, and the other as a PP Complement headed by <ment>from</ment>:
See Phenomenon_1, above. The phenomenon expressed less prominently as a PP complement is called <fen>Phenomenon_2</fen>:
Both phenomena that are potentially judged to be different from one another can be expressed jointly by the same constituent:

This is a property that is potentially used by the Cognizer to distinguish one phenomenon from another. It is normally expressed as a PP headed by a preposition such as <ment>from</ment>, <ment>by</ment>, or <ment>on the basis of</ment>:
The relatively locatable entity which serves as a basis for determining the location of the <fen>Trajector</fen> using the <fen>Profiled_region</fen>.
The location (located with respect to the <fen>Landmark</fen>) which is profiled by the particular image schema pertaining to the locative relation.
The entity which is construed to be in motion, whose location at the end of the construed motion event is in question.
The time at which the <fen>Trajector</fen> is located in the <fen>Profiled_region</fen>.
The <fen>Avenger</fen> exacts revenge from the <fen>Offender</fen> for the <fen>Injury</fen>.
The <fen>Offender</fen> has committed the earlier <fen>Injury</fen> for which the <fen>Avenger</fen> seeks revenge.
The <fen>Avenger</fen> carries out a <fen>Punishment</fen> in order to exact revenge on the <fen>Offender</fen>.

The <fen>Injury</fen> is the injurious action committed by the <fen>Offender</fen> against the <fen>Injured_Party</fen>. This Frame Element need not always be realized, although it is conceptually necessary.

This frame element identifies the constituent that encodes who or what suffered the <fen>Injury</fen> at the hands of the <fen>Offender</fen>. Sometimes, an abstract concept such a person's honour or their blood is presented as the element that has suffered the <fen>Injury</fen>. These also constitute instances of  <fen>Injured_party</fen>
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the revenge occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the revenge occurs.
The fire that Firefighters target.
The individual or group who respond(s) to the <fen>Fire</fen>.
The time when the Firefighter fights the Fire.
This role identifies the location of the Firefighters as they attempt to fight the Fire.
listRoleExamples: She was wearing a glove <fex>on one hand</fex>.
<fex>By five o'clock</fex>, he was wearing the old holey jeans and t-shirt again.
If <fex>we</fex> have not been able to resolve a problem to your satisfaction, please email us.
Likewise, once the students worked through <fex>the problem</fex> and obtained their results, their next assignment would be to publish these to the web.
First, <fex>the Tripartite Agreement of 1979</fex> actually solved the only significant friction between the two countries.
A group of international scientists solved the fundamental particle hierarchy question <fex>at an underground accelerator</fex>.
<fex>The teacher</fex> couldn't distinguish one child from the other.
The teacher couldn't distinguish Pat from Kim.
The teacher couldn't distinguish Pat <fex>from Kim</fex>.
The coach could distinguish the twins <fex>by their hair</fex>.
Jo had the affair as a kind of revenge <fex>against Pat</fex>.
The team took revenge <fex>with a resounding victory</fex>.
The team sought revenge <fex>for their 4-1 defeat last month</fex>.
